author: andreiiv.
content: Hi. 1.Are Hive Simulators hard coded scenarios or are those providing some higher level abstraction that could be scripted to produce quickly variants of scenarios?

author: andreiiv.
content: 2. Does Hive perform non-functional test (e.g., synchronization speed, transaction throughput, ...) or is it focusing on functional tests?

author: andreiiv.
content: 3. is Hive using internal APIs in clients or is it restricting itself to public APIs and focus on client inter-operability?

author: marioevz
content: It really depends on the simulator, all simulators are implemented in golang, but some of them import vectors from outside sources (e.g. https://github.com/ethereum/hive/tree/master/simulators/ethereum/consensus, or https://github.com/ethereum/hive/tree/master/simulators/ethereum/rpc-compat) and others do the hard-coded approach (e.g. https://github.com/ethereum/hive/tree/master/simulators/ethereum/engine)

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: You can also write simulators in different languages

author: marioevz
content: No performance testing so far in any of the simulators, most of them do functional testing yes

author: marioevz
content: All is public APIs, clients are configured via `HIVE_` parameters, but the way these are handled can be seen in the bash configuration scripts in each client: https://github.com/ethereum/hive/tree/master/clients
